Then I realized, after reading a lot of the 6,625 (as of 2022 02 27) comments that

1. from the lab frame of reference, with a current in the wire and the cat standing still, only the electrons are moving and therefore only the electrons undergo lorentz contraction. But

2. from the moving frame of reference (cat moving along with the electrons), the electrons are not contracted (because they are not moving relative to the cat). But everything else is contracted, including the SPACE between the positive charges.

So in the first case, the charge density isn't affected. The negative charges were length contracted, but the space was not. So there is still the same amount of charge per unit length of wire.

In the second case, though, the charge density IS affected. The space contracts, putting the positive charges closer together and increasing the positive charge density.

Special Relativity teaches us that all inertial reference frames are equally valid and equally fundamental. If two marbles roll past each other, then from the red marble's point of view the red marble is motionless and the blue marble is moving. From the blue marble's point of view the blue marble is motionless and the red marble is moving. Both viewpoints are equally correct and equally fundamental. The fact that the two marbles see the situation differently does not indicate that there is a paradox, that physics is broken, or that one viewpoint is ultimately more right than the other. It just means that the situation is being measured in two different reference frames. There are no "wrong" reference frames or less-fundamental reference frames in the universe. Therefore, a magnetic field cannot be only an electric field as viewed from the wrong reference frame because there are no wrong reference frames. Since there exists an inertial reference frame in which a magnetic field exists without an electric field being present, and since every inertial frame is real and fundamental, this means that a magnetic field is real, is fundamental, and is not necessarily caused by an electric field.

EDIT: The reason why a stationary (say electron) at some distance from a conducting wire will not be repelled from the wire if it is carrying an electrical current in which the charge carriers are electrons is a follows:
The stationary electron does indeed view the moving electrons (or better, the distance between them) to be length contracted so overall the density of electrons on the wire from the standpoint of the stationary electron will be greater than the density of positive ions that are not moving relative to the lone electron outside the wire. The wire then is perceived as overall negatively charged. But why no repulsion? This is because of Coulombs Law. It turns out that Coulombs law only strictly applies to charges that are stationary with respect to each other. If they are moving with respect to each other, you need to use a modified version. You can appreciate this by imagining that the electrical field that reaches each electron represents the position of the other electron in the past (just like the light from distant stars). This means that the force must not be representative of the 'instantaneous' distance, but some distance in the past. You might say that if you consider the symmetry of the situation as the electron passes the other that the effect would cancel out because some distances will have a positive correction and some will have a negative correction. But it does not the case here due to the inverse square relationship of force between individual charges (if someone is running backwards and forwards betwwen you to a distance 10m away, their average distance is 5m, but the average "squared distance" is further away). In any case the lone electron feels less repulsive force from the moving electrons that it does attractive force from the stationary positive ions which is EXACTLY cancelled out by the increased charge density of the electrons due to length contraction. Hence no overall attraction or repulsion.

Thus only when the lone electron is moving relative to the wire AND electrons are moving IN the wire things start getting interesting (i.e. what we call magnetism).

Everyone is still arguing over why the wire is not positively charged when the current is removed and the electrons expand. Well it's been seven years. I've watched this video dozens of times, and I've finally figured it out. Imagine an entire electric circuit. I.e. a battery (or capacitor, or whatever), with a loop of wire going from one terminal to the other. The total number of electrons in the circuit is constant (because due to relativity, charge must remain constant). If we start with the battery disconnected, everything is fine. The electron density matches the proton density, and the wire has no net charge. When we connect the battery, electrons start to flow. Let's imagine that they do contract in our reference frame. The total number of electrons must stay the same within our circuit, so where did the extra electrons come from? The answer is that when the electrons contract, the negative charge increase causes the electrons to repel each other back to a neutral net charge state. The result is that the electrons themselves get smaller, but they move father away from each other (back to a no current spacing) such that the net charge in the wire is still neutral. This also means that the total number of electrons in our circuit, and the electron density does not change. And thus, the wire has no net charge whether current is flowing or not (within our reference frame). Now from the moving reference frame of the cat, with no current flowing in the circuit, the electrons as well as the wire and battery contract equally, maintaining zero net charge. But when current is flowing, there will be a point in the circuit where electrons are flowing the same direction as the observer, and a point in the circuit where the electrons are flowing opposite the observer. Where they are moving in the same direction, they expand, reducing in density, and creating a net positive charge. But where they move in the opposite direction, they contract, creating a net negative charge. All that has happened is the density of electrons within the circuit has been redistributed. However the total number of electrons within the circuit still remains the same. The force that the charged cat experiences is the difference between the positively charged portion of the circuit, and the negatively charged portion. If the positively charged portion is (physically) much closer to the cat, a net repulsion force is experienced.

For those (still) struggling with why when the cat is not moving there's no attractive force making it move towards the wire, consider the following: The fact that the wire has no net charge when the electrons are moving can be considered a postulate (i.e. an assumption) of the experiment. This is reasonable because it's actually what is observed in real life, on a wire with current flowing through it. Put in relativistic terms, from the stationary cat/protons rest frame, the observed distance between the (moving) electrons is the same as the observed distance between the protons, therefore net zero charge density and no electric field. Note that under this assumption, the explanation that a moving cat will be repelled by the wire still holds: when changing to the reference frame of the moving cat, distance between electrons will increase (they are now slower in this frame, therefore less length contraction) and distance between protons will decrease, resulting in an electric field with a net positive charge.

If you still want to think about the length contraction of the moving electrons from the stationary cat/protons rest frame, realise that "length contraction" is a concept referring to the difference in observed length of something (or just space itself) being measured from two different frames. If you're measuring from just one frame, it doesn't matter if the electrons are moving or not, they will always be at the same distance.

From this last point, you might wonder what happens if you see a ruler start moving faster and faster from your frame of reference, shouldn't it length contract? If we imagine the full circuit, i.e. including the battery which pushes out the electrons (for simplicity assume that the electrons are injected from the left and absorbed on the right), then in the frame of the cat the "battery" is moving and hence its "clock" runs slow. In other words, as far as the cat is concerned the battery pushes out electrons at a lower rate, and hence the density is less.

The distance between ions is contracted (along with the battery and the rest of the circuit, and including the space between the electrons) as explained in the video.

Also note that in the example the magnetic field according to the cat is not zero, as there is still a current of ions. So it is not true that the magnetic field simply gets "converted" into an electric field and so it is not true that a magnetic field is "explained" by special relativity. It just means that "the" electric and magnetic field are relative concepts (depending on your motion), just like space and time.

This is just an intuitive thought though, so those who have more in-depth knowledge please correct me if I'm wrong. Here is my explanation:

The video is fantastic! But it does get one thing wrong. When the cat is stationary, and current flows in the wire, negative charges are not the only ones moving. When you have flow of charge through a conductor you need to have equal and opposite flow of positive and negative charges in order to not have any charge buildup. This would be akin to having some system that circulates water around, and for some reason the return pipe is clogged and pressure builds up as water flows in from the other side.

In reality, both the negative and positive charges in the wire are moving at equal and opposite velocities. They are appearing to contract from the standpoint of the cat, but since they are both contracting in the same way, they cancel, and there is no net force on the cat.

Now push the cat and give it a velocity in the direction of the current. Now one of the charge velocities appears to be going faster, and the other slower (sort of like driving on the freeway where cars on your side appear to be going slower from your point of view, and cars to the other side are going freakishly fast since they are heading in the opposite direction). Now the length contractions differ, and not only that, but they work against each other and create a net contraction twice that of what you would experience with a single line of moving charge. This creates a new electric force that we call magnetism!

I got it! I finally got it! I was wondering, from the stationary point of view, why the electrons don't contract and attract the positive cat. It is because from the moving cat's point of view the entire world - the positive nuclei and the wire along with it - is moving. That is why the space between the positive charges contract. Because that space itself (i.e. the wire they're in) is moving in this frame of reference.

From the stationary point of view, however, only the electrons themselves are moving. This only means that the electrons are squished down a bit and get flatter, but the space between them (again, the conducting wire) is stationary. Therefore the distance between charges remains the same and there is no change in the charge density.

Edit: It turns out this intepretation is not entire correct. In a simplified scenario of two co-accelerating bodies there are basically two possibilities (or more like two ends of a spectrum). If the distance between them stay constant from the bodies' pov it will contract from an observer's pov. If the distance stays constant from an observer's pov it will expand from the bodies' pov. It depends on how/when that acceleration is applied to the different bodies. Look up Bell's spaceship paradox for more info.

This is an impressive explanation of a very tricky phenomenon.  There are a lot of subtleties to this, and the video gets them all correct (very impressive).

One question that seems to be bothering a lot of people is why the wire is still neutrally charged in Mr. Muller's frame when the electrons are flowing.  The short answer is that the electrons starting to move is NOT a change in reference frame.

Imagine a line of evenly spaced cars along a freeway, initially all at rest.  At some pre-arranged time, the cars begin to accelerate at identical uniform rates.  As time passes, the cars will move faster and faster, but the distance between them as measured by a stationary observer on the freeway will not change.  This is obviously true in classical physics, and special relativity doesn't change that.

(However, the distance between the cars as measured by passengers in the cars does change!  That's what "makes magnetism work" so to speak--and that's what this video explains so well.)

To put it another way: If the flow of current DID cause the electrons to become denser in the wire, that would mean that from the observer's point of view, more electrons have to enter the wire.  Where do they come from?  In a wire attached to a battery or a generator, you could say that the power supply pushes more electrons into the circuit.

But what about a current induced by a magnetic field in a closed loop of wire?  This can be done by moving a closed loop of wire through a magnetic field (in fact, our civilization is pretty much dependent on it!)  If the flow of current causes the electron density in the wire to increase, and you induce a current in a closed loop of wire by moving it through a magnetic field, where do these electrons come from?  There's no place they could come from!

In the frame with the cat at rest the conductor is neutral before there is current. After there is current length will contract, but for the electron density to increase everywhere in the conductor more electrons are needed. If you have:

One unit of positive charge (+q) moving with a velocity (relative to the observer) of +v
with a position of +x(t) (relative to the observer)

and

one unit of negative charge (-q) moving with a velocity (relative to the observer) of -v
with a position of -x(t) (relative to the observer)

... then the increase of the length contractions from both charges should match, but given that they are of opposite charges, the result is that no magnetic force is exerted on a test charge placed at rest at the observer's location and inertial frame of reference. That does not mean there are no magnetic field "rings" ("seen" by the observer). They are certainly there. If you dislocate the test charge by moving it away from that observer (and therefore changing its frame of reference), a Lorentz force can be observed because the test charge moves relative to the magnetic field "rings" ("seen" by the observer).

What this means is that the magnetic field rings of current flowing in a conductor are not at rest with the conductor, but rather they move at a velocity between that of the free electrons and that of the metal ions of the conductor.

Therefore, if we suppose a different frame of reference for another observer, in a coordinate system of which electrons were to travel at, say, 100 km/h (in that frame of reference), the magnetic field "rings" around the conductor would move in the direction of these electrons at 50 km/h (in that frame of reference), in the case that we assume the conductor (copper atoms, silver atoms, whatever) to remain at rest in that frame of reference. The Lorentz force tells us that a magnetic field moving (in that frame of reference) generates an electrical field (in that frame of reference). In this case, the magnetic field "rings" move longitudinally along the wire (in that frame of reference) which generates an electrical field (E) pointing perpendicular toward the wire (in that frame of reference), indicating an apparent negative charge.

If instead the rest frame of that observer was that of the negative charge, the wire would appear to have a positive charge with an electrical field (E) pointing away from the wire.

Only when, in our frame of reference, we are stationary with the magnetic field "rings", does the wire appear completely neutral (i.e. with no electric field (E) pointing toward or away from the wire). Note that the drift velocity of actual electrons in a conductor is quite small even when passing high amounts of current. The drift velocity is usually on the order of mm per second. If we used a superconductor, the obtainable drift velocity could be much higher.

The difference of apparent charge density as observed among different frames of reference therefore arises not as the result of a real increase of electrons over that of protons in the wire (whether in quantity or density), but rather it results from the laws of electromagnetic induction.

Do note that the electric field of a charged particle at a given distance (r) depends not only on the quantity of charge (q), but also the electrical permittivity (ε) at the point where the electric field is measured. So it is not, in general, necessarily the case that the presence of electric fields lines pointing toward or away from the wire indicates the presence of a net charge.

However, as soon as we assume the first of Maxwell's four equations (Gauss' law), such electric fields lines pointing toward or away from a wire must imply a presence of net charge.  However, the divergence of the fourth of Maxwell's four equations (Ampère's circuital law (with Maxwell's addition)) derives the continuity equation for electric charges, which requires the conservation of charge with time. This implies that if we hold the interpretation of the magnetic field as being due to length contraction of electric fields to be self-evident, then the result will be that charge is not invariant (among a various frames of reference) although being conserved (as viewed from a given frame of reference).

The previous paragraph is invalid if we are speaking of a closed surface in spacetime (3 dimensions of space and 1 dimension of time), in which case the electric potential not only has a gradient with respect to each spatial domain, but also a gradient with respect to the time domain as well. Only in this case do Maxwell's equations and the related Lorentz transformations allow for charge to be invariant (not just conserved). In this case, we have an electric field that is defined in 4 dimensions instead of 3. This is the case derived from the Covariant Formulation of Electromagnetism. In essence, any deviation in the electric field observed in the three spatial dimensions of spacetime, that varies from what would be expected from the actual charge of the wire, is compensated for by an electric field that exists on the time axis. What such an electric field (existing on the time axis of spacetime) does to a charge is apparently to subject it to an electrical potential derived from a charge from a different point in time (i.e. from the past if one wishes to preserve the common sense notion of causality).

Now let's entertain a truncated view, where the real electric field exists in three dimensions (per aether theory), not four (per special relativity theory)!

The standard view (Coulomb Gauge) is that if the point where the electric field is measured exists in a vacuum, then regardless of the relative velocity of the charge with respect to the observer, this value depends on the electric permittivity of free space (ε sub 0) or "epsilon sub zero", which is a constant. Why? Electrical permittivity in the standard view describes the local properties a dielectric medium responding to the gradient of electrostatic potentials, resulting in a local electric field which depends on those properties. Therefore the electric field lines through a closed surface, in the standard view, is independent of the velocities of the charges contained in the volume that surface encloses. But this would mean this (first) standard view contradicts another (second) standard view, that length contraction of electric fields can explain magnetism by implying different a different charge (positive, neutral, or negative), depending on the frame of reference. This can be corrected by modifying the first standard view to say that it is wrong to assume that electric permittivity describes only local properties of the medium.

The previous paragraph and the ones following do not take into account the aspect of the standard view mentioned prior, which requires that, in the context of special relativity, the electric potential, as well as its corresponding gradient, to exist in four dimensions. Instead, these paragraphs apply to the truncated standard view (outside of special relativity) where electric fields are seen to be existing in three dimensions, especially by most practicing electrical engineers (rather than mathematical physicists who study four-dimensional spacetime). As such, among electrical engineers with only slightly above average knowledge of relativity, we have notions of variance of "charge" with respect to different frames of reference, as used by these people to explain the connection between electricity and magnetism from a current-carrying wire (as the video by Veritasium attempts). In classical aether theories, there is no "metric space" consisting of both space and time, and thus a classical aether theory proposing the invariance of charge with respect to different observers must interpret differently the actual experimental measurements and calculated values derived from theory. Classical aether theory does not support an electric potential gradient existing on the time axis.

In the truncated view (electric and magnetic fields existing only in three dimensional space), does the "charge" of the wire (q) really vary depending the frame of reference? Maybe not. Perhaps it is the electrical permittivity of particles comprising the metal atoms and the free electrons which depends on frame of reference (or in turn, the relative velocity of these charges in the frame of reference of the observer). Note that this requires electrical permittivity to be a function of the relative velocity of the electric field source / sink. This would allow for invariance of charge (q) in the truncated view, while still preserving the relationship between electricity and magnetism (that the video by Veritasium attempted to establish in the separate, standard, context of special relativity). Said another way, the alternative, truncated view suggests that the integration of the electric field (E) (units of V/m) over a closed surface (units of V times m) containing only one moving electron will result in a value which varies with the velocity of the charge relative to the surface (a surface defined in the coordinates of the observer's frame of reference), while the integration of the electric displacement field (D) (units of q/m^2) over the same closed surface (units of q) does not vary with that same velocity.

.... Alternatively, applying invariance of a "charge" to the truncated view could imply the opposite. That is to say that instead perhaps the closed surface integration of E, not D, is what remains constant regardless of the velocity of the electron enclosed in that surface. In this case, a "charge" of quantity V times m (= q / (q / (V times m))) is conserved as opposed to a "charge" of quantity q. V times m (volts times meters) shares the same units as electric flux, and thus this second alternative implies the invariance of electric flux though a closed surface, though not necessarily of charge. This is not to be confused with conservation of electric flux through a closed surface. General conservation of a quantity (substance) is attained by a continuity equation, while invariance of this quantity is obtained by comparing integrations calculated in the various proper coordinate systems assigned to inertial frames of reference of separate, distinct observers.
